item.content:encoded:
Final Fantasy 7 Remake series director has revealed how Cloud‚Äôs iconic Buster Sword almost received a more realistic version.

The Final Fantasy 7 Remake series director, Naoki Hamaguchi, has revealed quite a few details about Part 3 in recent days. He revealed that the game experience is ‚Äúmore or less complete‚Äù and has narrowed the title down to two options. Now he has provided a small tidbit on the questions they pondered while creating the Buster Sword for FF7 Remake.

During an interview with Julien Chi√®ze on YouTube (via GamesRadar+), Naoki Hamaguchi spoke about Final Fantasy 7 Remake‚Äôs Buster Sword. For those unaware, the Buster Sword is an iconic weapon wielded by Cloud Strife, known for its massive size. The director revealed that during the development process, there were discussions about the ‚Äúaspect of the weight‚Äù and how Cloud swinging an enormous sword with one hand would ‚Äúweaken the sense of realism‚Äù.

So at the time, the development team considered creating a ‚Äúmore realistic version of the Buster Sword‚Äù for Cloud to wield in Final Fantasy 7‚Äôs Remake. However, they decided against it as ‚Äúit was just too iconic, and if we‚Äôd made it just a regular old sword, players wouldn‚Äôt accept it.‚Äù Hamaguchi concluded, stating that ‚Äústayed faithful to the OG‚Äù in the end and ‚Äúa whole new generation of people fell in love with it, so I think it was the right call.‚Äù

item.title: Capcom Aims to Make New Projects for Devil May Cry, Mega Man and Ace Attorney
item.content:encoded:
A new report by Capcom reveals that they will bring new releases and remakes of Devil May Cry, Mega Man, and Ace Attorney to new hardware.

Capcom has some massive franchises under its belt, which include Resident Evil, Monster Hunter, and Street Fighter. However, they also have smaller franchises, which have a considerable user base. Capcom has stated that it will work to bring more projects for these franchises as well.

Devil May Cry, Ace Attorney, and Mega Man to Receive New Projects, Remakes, and Ports

Spotted by Rockman Corner, Capcom has released its 2025 integrated report, in which COO Haruhiro Tsujimoto has spoken about developing new projects, remakes, and ports for its other IPs. The statement first talks about Capcom aiming to sustain their ‚ÄúKPI of 10% or better annual operating profit growth along with our long-term goal of annual software sales of 100 million units.‚Äù Their efforts are ‚Äúfocused on core IP such as the Resident Evil, Monster Hunter, and Street Fighter franchises, and mapping out mainline series entries and sequels, remakes, new IP, and ports of content to the latest hardware.‚Äù

The statement adds that the developers release ‚Äútwo or three major new titles each year,‚Äù but have recognised they need to grow their pipeline. Capcom owns popular IPs such as Devil May Cry, Ace Attorney, and Mega Man, and their goal is to expand the user base and improve performance ‚Äúthrough new releases, remakes, and ports of titles in these series to new hardware.‚Äù They will grow these franchises into core IPs ‚Äúby enhancing the brand power and cultivating loyal fan bases.‚Äù

In other news, Capcom stated that Resident Evil Requiem‚Äôs development started ‚Äúway before‚Äù RE Village. Additionally, a former Capcom designer recently stated that Palworld ‚Äúcrossed a line‚Äù.
